That is what that is specifically directed at. In terms of recent actions on the waterfront, I will repeat that our government never considered at any time using the defence forces.

This is an important piece of legislation. It has the support of both sides of the House and it will go well towards extending the life of the NRTC for another five years, allowing the ATC to get on and appoint two more commissioners to complete the complement of commissioners on the NRTC and get on and complete that road reform process. I do not think there is any argument at all in Australia about some of the achievements that have been gained by this nation from the work of the NRTC. It is currently undertaking some very important work for the government in terms of the possibilities of increasing mass limits across Australia, opening up critical corridors of roadways for increased mass limits, from 42½ tonnes to 45 tonnes, which has a massive economic benefit to the entire nation, but particularly to regional Australia. That is the work that the NRTC is undertaking at the moment. We would like to see that continue. This will enable that to continue to happen and I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I thank the committee. I thank the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) for his response. I make just a brief comment. I understand the circumstances in which military equipment is required in national disasters. If there was, for example, to be a chemical or industrial accident, there may be some need for some military assets to be moved, although my understanding of the circumstances would be that it would mainly be some people. It would not be equipment intensive, which is the sort of thing we are talking about here with moving lots of things across the land.

speech.para: In respect of the domestic violence situation and 41B(6)(g), I must say that, if there were to be some sort of terrorist or similar activity to which the minister referred, I would not have thought the response would be an armoured column moving down the road. There are obviously other responses that would be used if the defence forces were called upon. I must say I have great difficulty envisaging the circumstances in which this clause would be activated, even given the minister's answer. However, I do not propose to seek a division on the issue. It is a comparatively minor part of the bill and one which I hope we are not going to have to return to at any point in the future.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.11 p.m. to 12.23 p.m.

talk.start.para: —To conclude the comments that I was making prior to the division, whilst I cannot envisage a circumstance in which it would be necessary for substantial heavy equipment, of the sort that this bill refers to, to be transported around to deal with the types of contingencies mentioned by the minister, I nonetheless do not propose that we divide on it, on two bases that I would like to record. The first basis is the response provided by the minister, for which I thank him and which does clarify to some extent the government's expectations of the application of this clause.

speech.para: The second basis is that, under a worst-case scenario, even were it to be used in a manner that those on this side of the House—and also, I suspect, many other Australians—would have difficulty with, this bill does not of itself produce that outcome. It would be heads of power elsewhere that would facilitate a government decision to use the military in those ways. Even in a worst-case scenario, this bill would simply facilitate the transportation of the equipment rather than the authorisation of its use. On that basis, together with the minister's answer, for which I thank him, the opposition will continue its bipartisan support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND ENGINEERING COUNCIL REPEAL BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —In considering the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council Repeal Bill 1998 I would like to begin my remarks with a quotation from Carl Sagan. Carl Sagan, who died recently, was arguably the world's foremost promoter and communicator of science and science issues, and some of his views are very relevant to the consideration of this bill. He is reported as saying:

speech.para: We've arranged a global civilisation in which most crucial elements profoundly depend on science and technology. We have also arranged things so that almost no one understands science and technology. This is a prescription for disaster. We might get away with it for a while, but sooner or later this mixture of ignorance and power is going to blow up in our faces.

That is a very relevant thing to consider when we look at the provisions of this bill. This bill repeals the ASTEC Act, but does so in contemplation of the government's announced intentions of incorporating its functions, effectively, within the Prime Minister's Science, Engineering and Innovation Council, which will subsume most of the roles of ASTEC.

ASTEC's primary function was to ensure that the government was able to take advantage of the combined experience and expertise of Australia's most representative and important scientists and engineers so that it could incorporate those things within its ongoing policy initiatives. The council has served a number of useful functions over the years and has produced many interesting and worthwhile reports.

The new arrangements of the Prime Minister's Science, Engineering and Innovation Council will allow many of our premier bodies—for example, FASTS, the Federation of Australian Science and Technological Societies, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, the presidents of the Academy of Science and the Academy of Technological Sciences and other leading representatives of science in Australia—to meet together with our political leaders at the national level to ensure that they are well versed in the priorities of science and technology.

I wish I could say that I look forward to the future of that committee with optimism, but, given the government's performance in two years in office in relation to science and technology, I think we would have to take a fairly pessimistic view of the potential outcomes of this new arrangement. While the opposition supports the change in principle, and also a number of our science and technology representative bodies have also welcomed this change, we do so with the caveat and the reservation that this government has shown no tendency in the past to rate science and technology highly and to ensure that it is incorporated into its budget strategies or into its overall policy framework.

To look at this bill in context we must refer to the two previous budgets of this government. The reality is that in both of those budgets the science community, science and research in general have fared very badly under this government. One of its first decisions indeed set the tone for science and technology. One of the early decisions of this first Howard government—let us hope there is not a second—illustrates its attitude towards science and technology: the decision to relegate Australia's Chief Scientist from a full-time position to a one day a week job. How can anyone take science and technology seriously when the government demotes its chief scientist from a full-time position to a day a week? A day a week is simply an insult to the science and technology community, but does illustrate the government's attitude towards science and technology in general.

There are some other very specific facts which we need to review, to come to a more detailed conclusion about how the government regards science and technology, research and development in general. In its previous budgets, for example, it has cut back funding for research in general by somewhat over nine per cent in the first budget, with a further one per cent cut in the budget last year. The total cut is thus around 11 per cent in the first two years of the Howard government's office.

We have also seen this government dramatically cut university funding, and so, because science is quite expensive to do in universities, obviously university administrations will seek to cut their science and research organisations first. They will be the main losers in the context of those higher education cutbacks.

We saw the government honour their promise to increase funding to CSIRO only to see, basically, the whole amount of that increase taken back from CSIRO by increases in the efficiency dividend and by the requirement for CSIRO to make capital repayments to the government from the sale of assets and property. We saw, of course, most significantly, the dramatic cutback in general government assistance for research and development which was paid through the taxation concessions. The reduction from 150 per cent to 125 per cent was very significant and has had a real impact on business research and development expenditure.

Of course, the government also completely abolished the syndication taxation concession arrangements. They did that in a way that sought to imply that people taking advantage of those arrangements were tax rorters. Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) frequently refers to those science and technology taxation concessions as taxation rorts. Nothing could be further from the truth. While there is always the potential in any taxation concession for some dishonest people to try and exploit that, I think the syndication concession was very well arranged and ensured that only deserving projects were rewarded with the taxation concession. If there were any problems, the problems should have been tackled, not the overall scheme which did seek to bring together those who had good science with those who had surplus cash to ensure that the funding flowed to those innovative companies. However the government sought to cut that completely and that program has been abolished along with, as I say, the significant reduction from 150 to 125 per cent for the taxation concession.

Also, we saw the government virtually double the HECS contribution to science degrees and that will ensure that fewer students take science as a degree choice at university. Obviously, students respond to market signals like everyone else. They are aware that this government has sent them a very powerful message by doubling the HECS contribution for science degrees. It is a very powerful message, indeed, and one which we will regret in future years as the number of our young people who would have been able to undertake science degrees and make a substantial contribution to science in Australia are discouraged from taking that career option at universities.

We have also seen this government cut back on the CRC program, the cooperative research centre program. That was a very valuable program which ensured that there was science at the cutting edge of Australian industrial technology. It ensured that our best researchers, principally from the universities, were brought together in an entrepreneurial context with industry and best players in the public science bodies in a way which ensured that technology diffusion had the best possible opportunity to come to pass, with knowledge going from the universities through the CRCs and out into industry.

The program also served the very valuable function of encouraging large numbers of postgraduate students to work closely with industry and with the very best of our academic researchers to ensure that we have a trained and skilled pool of young people moving out into industry who are well aware of the needs of industry and yet carry with them the very best that our academic researchers can put forward. That was a very targeted program. And what has this government done? It has substantially cut the funding available to that. Again, that sends a very powerful message to industry, young people, universities, and to researchers in our CRC community that their work is not particularly valued, that it is reduced in value by this government, and that they have no real confidence for the future.

Indeed, the government was very destructive in the way in which it allowed Mortimer's recommendation to abolish the CRC program altogether to hang out there in the public view for months while it made up its mind whether it wanted to support that program in an ongoing way. While I agreed with many of Mortimer's recommendations, the particular one in relation to the CRC program was very ill-founded and very destructive. Unfortunately, instead of decisively rejecting that recommendation when it first came down, thereby sending the message to the CRCs that their work was indeed valued in our community, the government allowed that recommendation to stand in the community for months while it made up its mind whether it wanted to continue the program.

The budget of last night again reinforces the view that this government does not particularly value science, innovation, research and development. Indeed, again, the budget speech failed to emphasise any of those areas. I could not find any reference in the budget speech last night—as I could not particularly last year, or in previous years—to science, innovation, education, research and development.

The only reference in that area was to the NHMRC, which is health research, and that is questionable. My colleague the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) will no doubt say more about that in the future. But, apart from that one reference to medical research, there are no references in the budget to industrial R&D, to innovation in our manufacturing industry, to science or technology or education and the value which they bring to our young people and to the future of Australia.

talk.start.para: —You haven't read what the ministers have said.

—Clearly, the speech by the Treasurer on the night of the budget is the highlight of the budget process. If a government values a particular enterprise in our society well, it will ensure that that features in the budget speech. That is how you rate governments on matters of science and technology.
—On the length of the speech?

—Not on the length, no, but on the content. The content is highly relevant here. The Treasurer failed to take the opportunity to emphasise the importance of science and technology. Clearly, there were other areas which he thought it worth mentioning and they were highlighted. But science, technology, innovation, research, development and education—those critical things—were omitted from the Treasurer's speech. The relevance of it—
—They were in the budget papers and in the ministers' statements.
—Clearly, the important part from a government's point of view is the speech. That is where they should have been; that is where they were not. If you look—
—Labor never put anything about science in the budget speeches.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, apart from the fact those interjections are highly disorderly in this context, as I am sure you will indicate—
—Let me encourage you to ignore them.

—they are quite wrong. I will not be distracted by them, Mr Deputy Speaker, as I know you would not want me to be. Honourable members opposite want me to turn to the budget papers and to ignore the Treasurer's speech. There is always a temptation to ignore that speech. However, if we turn instead to the budget papers, as the honourable members opposite want me to, what, for example, should I quote from those? At random I will turn to chapter 4, page 19, where there is a very relevant quote on general research outlays which honourable members opposite are so fond of:

speech.para: Total outlays decline slightly over the forward estimates.
Note that, Mr Deputy Speaker: `decline' over the forward estimates. It goes on:
This is largely explained by a decline in ARC funding for research infrastructure, collaborative research grants and the High Performance Computing and Communications Programme.

So when one does refer to those budget papers, the very documents which honourable members sought to have me quote from, one sees, in the government's own word, that funding for research in general will decline in future years and that it will decline because of a reduction in ARC grants for research infrastructure as well as for collaborative research grants and high performance computing and communications. Those are very critical areas for the future of Australian science. But, again, not only does the government not mention them in the principal speech but also, when detailing them in its papers, it seeks to justify that massive decline in future years on spending on general research.

Why is this so important? The relevance of science and technology to economic development and jobs for our young people cannot be understated. The relevance of this was I think identified by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself following his recent trip to the United States. He met with a number of people, including the chair of the Federal Reserve over there, the equivalent of the chair of our Reserve Bank board, who I think educated the Prime Minister to some degree on the importance of IT in industrial development. Unfortunately, he should have broadened that understanding which he brought back from the United States about the importance of IT to the science and technology area in general. Research has shown quite clearly that some 40 per cent of all economic development in the United States post World War II—in the last 50 years—has been due to investments in the United States in science and technology, research and development, and innovation. So nearly half of all US growth in the last 50 years is due to investments in R&D.

If Australia is looking to have a place in the Pacific region in the next century, clearly we need to emulate that massive investment which the United States has made in R&D and replicate that here in Australia. If we do not, we run the risk of Australia becoming a low wage, low skill economy, rather than a high wage, high skill economy based on innovation arising from research and development conducted in our universities, in the CRCs and in industry generally.

Australia has always had a very good base of public sector investment in science and technology. Our CSIRO is a world famous organisation, justly so, because of the innovations which it has introduced over recent decades and the way in which it has translated those into useful products in industry. Also, in recent years, the previous government introduced the concept of the CRC program. That has been a very worthwhile innovation and one which has helped to diffuse that technology out into industry. Of course, we have yet to see this government respond in a positive way to any of those things.

If we are going to experience, as the budget paper points out, a significant decline in funding for general research—and the trend in the graph published in the budget paper is of something which is declining; it is a downward trending slope—if that is continued as the out years forecast in the budget papers predicts, then clearly Australia will not be in a position to respond to the globalisation of our economy, or to the increase in innovation which other substantial countries like the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany and France are experiencing. Particularly in the case of the US and the UK, they are experiencing substantial booms in their economy because of past investments in R&D. Despite this, the government here is only predicting a steady and certain decline.

If you look more closely at those figures you will see that some organisations are not in such a decline. For example, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation is due to experience very significant increases in its funding in future years. This is not because the government has singled out this agency for an increase; it is because this particular agency is to construct a new nuclear reactor on the Lucas Heights site. I will have more to say about that in another bill which is before this committee—it was to be debated later today but I assume it may now be tomorrow—in relation to radiation protection. Therefore, I will not canvass that at length now.

I want to contrast the increase in ANSTO funding with the substantial cut in Australian Research Council funding, which is also detailed in the budget paper. We see this nice matching progression, a steady increase for ANSTO to fund a nuclear reactor and a steady decline in ARC funding. Obviously, that is where the increases in ANSTO's funding has come from. The government has sacrificed the Australian Research Council funding to pay for its new nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights.

Because of past cuts in funding for ARC under this government, already only 19 per cent of grant applications lodged with the ARC by our young researchers are accepted. That means 80 per cent of those applications are declined. That is not because 80 per cent are in a poor state of science. It is because almost all of those cannot be funded by the available grants which the ARC has at its disposal.

When you get down to a level where only one-fifth of those grant applications are being approved, obviously they will go to those researchers with a proven track record of research in ARC's terms. The grants will not go to those who are young, innovative, or who are trying to break into this field. That is a very serious thing for our progress in the next century.

Also, this government will ensure that the 19 per cent figure declines even further because if we look to the out years, the funding for ARC for 1999-2000 will decline to $412 million; in 2000-2001 it will drop to $383 million; and in 2001-2002 it rises slightly to $390 million. That amount is some $50 million less than the current value of funding for ARC.

That is a very serious decline in funding. It has been brought about by the government's decision to increase the funding to ANSTO by about the same amount over that period. Obviously, the minister has sacrificed ARC in order to fund ANSTO. That is a very poor decision indeed. It shows a considerable lack of foresight and a significant lack of understanding of the way in which science, technology and innovation can feed back into our community and promote job growth in this country.

We largely have missed the IT bus. The reality is that this country does not have a leading position in relation to information technology. That is something which has occurred in recent years. While our Labor government was addressing that through a number of grants in innovation and the CRC program, I would certainly concede that more should have been done to address the IT issue during our term of government. However, this government has continued that trend. It has reduced funding for IT. It has removed the computer bounty, for example, and it has failed to see the benefits of information technology in a way which will feed back into the rest of the community.

Molecular biology, genetic engineering, is possibly the next cab off the rank. What does the government do in relation to that? Almost nothing. It is impossible to find in this budget document any real leadership in science and technology. So, while we might have reasonable hopes for the PMSEC arrangements which will replace those of ANSTO, I am afraid that an analysis—as I have undertaken this morning—of the government's trend in these areas clearly does not give us much confidence.

Again, this budget has failed to demonstrate the government's commitment to science and technology. It has reinforced that lack of commitment, lack of leadership and lack of vision on science and technology. This is not just a matter for political concern. It is, as I have said, a serious issue in the community where jobs are at stake and where growth in employment is at stake. This is not just about scientists in their laboratories. This is about providing jobs and economic growth for this country in the next century. Our young people will pay the price of the government's lack of vision.

There are to be new arrangements for introducing the Prime Minister to those best representatives of science in our community from the leading technological societies in our community. I only hope that exposure to those people over the next year or so will ensure that the government—in the remaining 12 months of its term, or however much less the Prime Minister may choose to allocate—and the Prime Minister are better educated about issues of science and technology and that his ministers can bring to the cabinet table a better understanding of the need for job growth in this area. If the opportunities are not provided in science, technology, research, development and innovation, as they ought to be, Australia will not be in for an innovative future in the next century. Rather, many of our young people will face the unfortunate choices of a low wage and low skilled future.

talk.start.para: —The Howard government is, above all else, a forward thinking government. We are a government planning and actively working towards making Australia competitive well into the 21st century. We are a government of vision and our vision is one of practical achievement. Last night's budget showed quite clearly that we are prepared to put in the hard yards now to secure a better future for all of our children. Paying back the massive debt left behind by Labor is a cornerstone of our forward planning.

speech.para: I am pleased to say that technology and research are also part of our plan for a modern and competitive Australia. That is why, upon coming to office, we identified the need to examine how Australian science and technology systems could be improved. The Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council Repeal Bill 1998 streamlines our current system winding down the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council. The current council is to become a standing committee of the Prime Minister's Science, Technology and Engineering Council.

This standing committee will maintain the key task of preparing issue papers and presentations to the Prime Minister's council and undertaking consultation, information gathering and analysis to provide the Prime Minister's council with information and advice on Australian science and technology priorities. However, we have been careful to ensure that the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council maintains its independence. Indeed, the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss), in his second reading speech, outlined how the government values the independent role played by ASTEC.

As the minister said, we have been carefully planning this bill to capitalise on the strengths of the current system while addressing some of its weaknesses. It seems commonsense to me to draw closer together the Prime Minister's advisory council and ASTEC. The ASTEC can still carry out its normal duties and information gathering but it now has a direct line to the ministry. It is a delivery mechanism that ASTEC has not enjoyed in the past and I am sure it will bring future benefits for Australian science and technology.

Of course, the reason science and technology is important is not merely for academic purposes—we are not into `esoteric' visions—it is also that the Howard government is focused firmly on practical achievements. Scientific and technology developments benefit society in many ways. New developments help generate economic growth. While I am speaking of growth, I will take the opportunity to congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on meeting the growth forecasts in last night's budget and for the continued expected growth of around three per cent, despite the Asian economic crisis. Last night's budget clearly has us back on track and back in the black. The reaction I have had in my conversations with local Forde residents this morning has been extremely positive.

As well as economic growth, new technology developments help improve our health, help us find even better ways to protect our environment and help us to maintain our national security. There can be little doubt that our technological achievements over this century have dramatically improved our quality of living and have given us a whole range of new recreational and vocational pursuits. I am pleased to be a part of a government which is wholeheartedly committed to technology and scientific development. Our budget commitment regarding new software and the millennium problem will be a great boost to the information technology industry and it is indicative of our practical approach.

Can I say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we are in a much better position to look at expanding our focus and support for new technology in the future. We are in a much better position because the budget is back in surplus. As the Treasurer said, `Isn't a great problem to have to work out where we can spend future budget surpluses.'

Of course, in the short term, these have to go to pay back the huge government debt the Labor Party left behind, some $98 billion. But with things back on track, there will come a time when we are debt free as a nation and we can look at investing even more in emerging technology and scientific advancements. We have a proud history of achievement and the Howard government is committed to ongoing support for science and technology. Mindful of the time, I now commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I begin by thanking the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) and the honourable member for Forde (Mrs Elson) for their contributions to this debate, particularly the honourable member for Forde who took the opportunity to respond to some of the baseless allegations made by the member for Bonython in relation to the government's commitment to science and, in particular, the content of last night's federal budget.

speech.para: The honourable member for Bonython in a very eloquent way used typical Labor rhetoric to misrepresent the government's commitment to science and technology, but sadly demonstrated the sort of fiscal illiteracy that led to the $10.3 billion deficit. He accused the government of lacking a commitment to science but at least had the grace to admit later in his remarks that Labor had not done much in this field.

It is unfortunate, perhaps, that science and research and development issues do not gain much debating time in the House or the time of members of parliament in addressing the important issues for our country for the future. It is important that we have, as a nation, a commitment to science and a commitment to doing things better in the future.

It is just beyond question, in spite of the comments of the member for Bonython, that there is a very high level of government expenditure in Australia on research and development by world standards. At a government level we spend more on research and development than does the US or, indeed, other leaders of industry in the OECD.

Unfortunately, however, industry itself has not been quite so forthcoming and there has been a much smaller proportion of industry budgets spent on research and development. Whilst that problem has been improving over recent years and there has been increased expenditure by business on research and development, we still have some way to go to reach leading practice around the world in that regard.

The government is determined to ensure that there is additional expenditure and commitment to research and development issues and that was reflected in last night's budget. The 1998 budget increased expenditure on science and technology by $90 million overall. I am surprised that the member for Bonython, since he endeavoured to give the impression to the committee that he had studied the budget in detail, had not uncovered that very obvious and very important statistic.

There has been a particularly large increase in research and development in the health field, with major commitments in that regard and expenditure for the NHMRC up by nine per cent and in other health areas by 38 per cent. There is also support for industry and their efforts in research and development, with a 30 per cent increase in the Start program and IIF program.

The estimate for the expenditure on tax concessions for R&D is up by six per cent. Expenditure on science agencies, such as the CSIRO, ANSTO and AIMS, is up by 3.6 per cent. There is no diminution of the government's commitment to science in this budget. Indeed, there is a clear indication that there will be more money available and, indeed, that the government will be following on its rhetoric with classic action by delivering additional funds to ensure that we have adequate resources available to support industry and, indeed, to back up the government's own commitment to expenditure in science and research and development.

Turning particularly to the content of this bill, it implements changes announced by the government last year as an important element in improving Australia's science and technology administrative arrangements by bringing together the resources of ASTEC and the Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council, PMSEC, into one organisation. The new organisation has now been reconstructed as the Prime Minister's Science, Engineering and Innovation Council. It combines the ability to draw on the best independent advice available, conduct studies—as ASTEC does at present—and deliver outcomes direct to the federal ministry.

By repealing the ASTEC Act and implementing these new arrangements, the government will strengthen support for innovation and industrial growth. I note that the bill is supported by all sides of the House and I thank members opposite for their cooperation in that regard. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Was a light aircraft overturned by winds at Essendon Airport while engaged in pilot training on 16 August 1997; if so, is the incident being investigated by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation or the Federal Airports Corporation.
(2) What was the highest recorded wind speed at Essendon Airport on 16 August 1997.

(3) Are aircraft operations halted for safety reasons at Essendon Airport during strong winds; if so, at what wind speed; if not, will he ensure that restrictions are introduced in the interests of safety to pilots, passengers and nearby residents.
(4) On how many occasions since 1 January 1970 have aircraft operations been halted at Essendon on account of strong winds.
(5) On how many occasions since 1 January 1990 have recorded wind speeds at Essendon exceeded the maximum recorded on 16 August 1997.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Airservices Australia has advised that a light aircraft (Cessna 172) was overturned by a strong wind gust while lining up for departure on Runway 35 at Essendon on 16 August 1997 and was reported to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI). This accident was assessed as a category 5 occurrence by BASI.
Category 5 is reserved for occurrences where the facts, as revealed by the circumstances, clearly indicate no need for safety action by BASI.
A copy of the database record created by BASI as a result of this accident is attached.
(2) Airservices Australia has advised that the highest gust observed by the Tower controllers was 52 knots, shortly before the incident. The pilot had been advised of the wind at this time.

(3) Airservices Australia has advised that Air Traffic Control (ATC) does not close runways at Australian airports due to strong winds. Crosswinds and/or downwind components are the significant factors in aircraft operations. ATC is responsible for ensuring that a pilot is fully informed of the prevailing weather conditions to enable the pilot to make the relevant operational decisions.

It is the sole responsibility of the pilot to ensure the runway or direction nominated has sufficient length of run, and that the crosswind or downwind component is not greater than the maximum allowable for their aircraft in the prevailing conditions.
ATC shall not nominate a particular runway for use if an alternate runway is available, when:
(a) for runway conditions that are completely dry: (i) the crosswind component, including gusts exceeds 25 knots; (ii) the downwind component, including gusts, exceed 5 knots.
(b) For runway conditions that not completely dry: (i) the crosswind component, including gusts exceeds 25 knots; (ii) there is a downwind component.
A pilot may require the use of a runway which has wind characteristics different from the above limitations.
Restrictions to operations do occur by way of aircraft operational limitations applicable, varying from aircraft type to aircraft type, which are specified in aircraft operating manuals.
(4) Airservices Australia has advised that there is no data available to answer this question.
(5) Airservices Australia has advised that there is no data available to answer this question.
COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT—BUREAU OF AIR SAFETY INVESTIGATION
Brief Print (Public)
Injuries:
Occurrence Summary:

The tower controller cleared the pilot to line up on runway 35. When the aircraft entered the runway, it encountered a strong crosswind gust from the left and over-turned. About seven minutes earlier the surface movement controller had advised taxiing aircraft that the wind was gusting to 52 kts.
OASIS537 Printed on Tuesday 23 September 1997—10:19.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 2 October 1997:

question.para: (1) What are the details of legal and associated costs resulting from Native Title claims each year claims have been made.
(2) What is the source of funding for the costs referred to in part (1).

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The following information is provided on the costs associated with native title litigation in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs Commission, the Attorney-General's portfolio, and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

The allocation within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's (ATSIC's) budget for native title purposes provides funding under the Native Title programme for two broad categories—the operating costs of Native Title Representative Bodies (NTRBs), and the cost of implementing and supporting claims under the Native Title Act 1993 .

The implementation component of the programme is specifically for one-off costs associated with claim development such as legal, anthropological and research costs but also includes claim meetings, National Native Title Tribunal meetings and land tenure searches. ATSIC does not collect a breakdown of each individual cost item.

Under the operational component of the Native Title programme NTRBs also engage in-house legal expertise as part of their core staffing levels. Most NTRB core staffing levels are between 10 to 14 staff of which 1 to 2 are lawyers.
Details of ATSIC's Native Title expenditure since 1993 is shown in the following table:
Note * : Figures taken from the 1994/95 ATSIC Annual Report.
Note ** : Figures taken from ATSIC Financial Management Information System (FMIS), as at 3 February 1998. Figures will vary by the end of the 1997/98 financial year.
Expenditure details in relation to the National Native Title Tribunal and Legal Aid support to native title clients, which fall within the Attorney-General's portfolio, are as follows:
* To 31 March 1998
** Attorney-General's portfolio budget statements

The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is responsible, on behalf of the portfolio Minister, for providing instructions on native title litigation to which the Commonwealth is a party. Some of the Department's Running Costs and Compensation and Legal expenditure have resulted from native title litigation since it undertook this role. However it is impracticable to identify these costs discretely as they represent only a portion of the total costs under these items.
There has been no expenditure to date on native title cost sharing with the States and Territories.

The Government has offered to contribute to States and Territories, in broad terms, 75 per cent of their past act and intermediate act compensation costs and 75 per cent of their future act compensation costs arising from the 10-point plan. It has also offered to pay, until five years after the enactment of the 10-point plan amendments, 50 per cent of the administrative costs of State and Territory recognised bodies and alternative right to negotiate regimes.

The offer is subject to conditions, including that if native title (along with other rights in the land) is acquired in order to grant a new interest in land the beneficiary of the grant must pay a proper financial contribution.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Wingz North and Heli Adventure
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2583)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 December 1997:

question.para: (1) Further to the claims made by the Member for Leichhardt (Hansard , 25 November 1997,page 11003) in relation to the actions of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) against Wingz North and Heli Adventure, what were the actions taken by CASA in relation to Wingz North and referred to by the Member.
(2) Did CASA ever express concerns about the safety of Wingz North's operations; if so, what were the concerns.
(3) Did CASA require Heli Adventure's chief pilot to be tested on the B206 type helicopter; if so, is this normal procedure.
(4) Was it possible to undertake testing in Cairns; if not, why not.

(5) Did CASA determine that Captain McGowan was unsuitable to be Heli Adventure's chief pilot because he had been in Cairns for only a short period; if so, (a) what criteria applied in making the decision and (b) on what regulations was the decision based.
(6) Has he or his predecessor received correspondence or other representations on the matter from the Member or the companies involved.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) CASA suspended the Air Operators Certificate (AOC) of Wingz North on 19 February 1997 for serious breaches of the Civil Aviation Regulations including overloading of aircraft. A notice outlining the reasons for the suspension was delivered on that date to the operator, Gary Maile Investments Pty Ltd.
(2) Yes. CASA expressed concern about the safety of Wingz North's operation in:
. 33 Non Compliance Notices issued to Wingz North by CASA in the period 4 October 1995 to 19 February 1997;
. the Suspension Notice dated 19 February 1997;
. the Affidavit of Robert Collins, District Flying Operations Manager, Cairns District, CASA, sworn on 4 March 1997 and filed in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
The most serious of these concerns related to alleged overloading of Wingz North aircraft and the unauthorised carriage of dangerous goods.

(3) Yes. CASA required Heli Adventure's Chief Pilot to be tested on the B206 type helicopter. On 7 October 1997 CASA advised Mr Pagget of Helico Pty Ltd of a date for Mr Rock's Chief Pilot interview and that a flight check would be required. It is normal procedure for CASA to flight check a prospective Chief Pilot. Since the Monarch and Seaview inquiries it has been recommended that all new Chief Pilots receive a flight check unless their competency is known to CASA through other means, i.e having worked for another company where flight surveillance was carried out as part of CASA's surveillance program.

(4) Yes. The flight check was conducted in Cairns by the Flying Operations Inspector from the Townsville District Office, as the Cairns Office does not have a qualified helicopter Flying Operations Inspector.
(a) CASA considered it imperative that, in order to satisfactorily supervise the company's operations, it should have a full time Chief Pilot who was a resident of Cairns.

On 23 September 1997, CASA wrote to Helico acknowledging receipt of Mr McGowan's nomination as Chief Pilot advising that the position would require full time residence in Cairns and asking if Mr McGowan was agreeable to relocate to Cairns. If Mr McGowan had been agreeable to this, arrangements would have been made to interview him. Subsequently, CASA was advised that Mr McGowan, who was a resident of Sydney, was not agreeable to this arrangement.
(b) Section 28BB (1) of the Civil Aviation Act allows conditions to be imposed on an AOC where it is necessary in the interests of aviation safety.
(6) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 4 December 1997:

question.para: (1) How many single voyage permits were approved (a) in 1996-97 and (b) from 1 July to 30 September 1997.

(2) What are the details of (a) the cargoes and tonnages carried and (b) the ports of origin and destination associated with each single voyage permit approved (i) in 1996-97 and (ii) from 1 July to 30 September 1997.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) Data for 1996-97 was collected on the basis of permits actually used, whereas data for the September quarter 1997 was collected on the basis of permits approved.
(a) and (b) Details of cargo, tonnages and ports of destination and origin of the single voyage permits.
(i) actually used during 1996-97 is at Table 1. (There were 595 single voyage permits approved, 572 of which were actually used.)
(ii) approved from 1 July 1997 to 30 September 1997 is at Table 2.
TABLE 1

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) What soldering jobs were to be performed using the equipment referred to in the tender for soldering stations, reference CNA/4165/2/74.

(2) Did the tender specify that the iron temperature must either be microprocessor controlled with tip temperature digitally regulated, monitored and displayed or incorporate self regulating AC skin effect heating where the temperature is determined by the inherent alloy composition of the tip; if so, (a) why, (b) how does the specification comply with performance requirements rather than product specification requirements and (c) did Australian tenders meet the specification.

(3) Did Loadline Australia Pty Ltd respond to the tender; if so, would the soldering system it offered be capable of doing the soldering jobs which were to be performed by the equipment sought in the tender; if not, why not; if so, did the tender exclude the type of soldering system offered by Loadline and if so, why.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The equipment is used during diagnosis and fault finding of aircraft component circuit boards prior to the board being rebuilt and hermetically sealed in the Micro Miniature Component repair laboratory.
(2) Yes.

(a) Microprocessor design allows simple and inexpensive upgrading through reprogramming of the Read Only Memory (ROM) as opposed to analogue systems which generally require the replacement of the controller, which is the major cost of the system. In addition, microprocessor control allows for features such as:
(i) temperature off-set for different tip temperature profiles;
(ii) temperature idle which drastically extends iron and tip life, hence reducing life cycle cost;
(iii) more accurate control of temperature over a wider range, as the thermocouple characteristics, which are non linear, are stored in the ROM.

(b) Prior to drafting the specification for this procurement an extensive review of industry and international Defence capability was undertaken. The review identified a need for a solder station that would provide the same level of control and quality required in the Micro Miniature Component Repair laboratories, without the associated accessories. The identified capability reduces the likelihood of waste through heat damage to boards and components during the diagnosis and fault finding procedures. It was determined that a performance specification did not guarantee that the identified capability would be delivered therefore a technical specification was seen as the best option in this case.
(c) Offers of technically compliant Australian made equipment were received.

(3) Loadline Australia Pty Ltd did respond to the tender. The equipment offered by Loadline Australia Pty Ltd represented the same generation of analogue equipment that was to be replaced and did not provide the capabilities sought to reduce the potential for heat damage to circuit boards. The aim of this tender was to provide a unit that would give the user greater control during the diagnosis and fault finding procedures than could be provided by the current generation of equipment. The tender excluded the type of equipment offered by Loadline Australia Pty Ltd because it could not provide the additional capability sought.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Can Australian Defence Force Academy (ADFA) cadets receive credits for their studies at ADFA when they leave the ADF and transfer to another tertiary institution; if so, under what circumstances.
(2) Is she able to say whether some Australian tertiary institutions do not recognise ADFA's undergraduate subjects; if so, (a) which institutions and (b) why are the subjects not recognised.
(3) Does the Department of Defence provide assistance to cadets who resign from ADFA and wish to complete their tertiary studies at another Australian tertiary institution; if so, what assistance.

talk.start.para: —The honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Cadets leaving ADFA, having partially completed a degree, may apply for admission to another (civilian) tertiary institution. It is the prerogative of the admitting institution to determine the amount of credit to be granted.

(2) The University College at ADFA is not aware of any institution refusing credit for mainstream subjects in equivalent degree courses. If a cadet was seeking entry to a different course, for example, architecture, after taking arts subjects at the University College, some of the subjects completed at ADFA may not be credited as they would not be relevant to the new degree. The University of New South Wales has a policy of requiring all students to complete general education subjects in their degree, amounting to the equivalent of one first year subject. These are subjects outside the discipline of the degree, for example, humanities subjects in an engineering degree. In some circumstances other tertiary institutions may decide not to grant credit for general education subjects.

(3) Cadets who resign from ADFA but remain in the ADF may be provided with education assistance under one of the ADF Education Assistance Schemes, to complete tertiary studies at tertiary institutions around Australia, dependent on Service requirements and degree programs. Cadets who resign from the ADF do not receive any further education assistance to complete tertiary studies.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies Courses
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2608)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the duration of courses run by the Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies (ACDSS) and the Joint Staff College (JSSC) been reduced from 12 months to 6; if so, why.
(2) What priority is given to the participation of officers from other regional forces in ACDSS and JSSC programs.
(3) What impact will reduced course arrangements have on regional participation.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (2) and (3) As part of the implementation of the Defence Reform Program, the Chief of the Defence Force has directed that a new higher Defence course for senior officers, to replace the JSSC and the ACDSS courses, be developed. Studies to support this are underway. Decisions on course structure, curriculum, and the composition of the student body will be made in due course but we will continue to offer places to officers from countries in our region.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: Is he able to say to which international (a) organisations and (b) instruments the UK has become party since the election of the Blair Government and on what dates.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) The United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO).
(b) A list of instruments to which the United Kingdom has signed or to which it has become bound, following the election of the Blair Government in May 1997, is attached.
